evidence.pdf_reference: based product e.g., methanol and formic acid was produced only during CO 2 reduction in the presence of catalyst and light irradiations.Recently similar method has been reported for blank test to confirm source of carbon in products 34.All experiments were repeated at least three times consecutively to check the reliability of the obtained results. The effect of Cu loading on the activity of TiO 2 and g-C 3 N 4 for CO 2 reduction to methanol and formic acid under both visible and UV light are presented in

and UV light are presented in Fig. 10.The effectiveness of the catalyst samples were analysed based on the yield of CH 3 OH and HCOOH which were the two main products from the process.As seen in Fig. 10(a) and (b), the yield of CH 3 OH increases with increasing Cu loading till it attained an optimum yield when doped with 3 Cu beyond which the yield starts to decline.This trend is the same for both UV and visible light, although the yield of CH 3 OH for 3 Cug-C 3 N 4 is higher than that of 3 CuTiO 2 and

formation of a heterostructure comprising of g-C 3 N 4 and 3 CuTiO 2 in the 30:70 ratio produces a suitable composite photocatalyst with increased charge separation and lower recombination rate. For quality assurance and to ascertain correct results, blank tests were performed in the dark with the catalyst and CO 2 and in the light and catalyst without CO 2 under the same experimental conditions.The carbon based products were not detected in either case.Therefore, any carbon based product e.g., methanol

Cu-modified graphitic carbon nitride (g-C 3 N 4 ) and titanium dioxide (TiO 2 ) nanocomposites for enhanced photocatalytic CO 2 reduction with H 2 O under UV and visible light irradiations have been investigated.The photocatalysts, prepared by pyrolysis and impregnation were characterized by XRD, FE-SEM, TEM, FT-IR, N 2 adsorption-desorption, XPS, UV-vis DRS and PL spectroscopy.The Cu-metal loaded over TiO 2 and g-C 3 N 4 enhanced CO 2 reduction efficiency to CH 3 OH and HCOOH by fostering carrier charge

catalyst composites for both UV and visible light is exhibited in Considering the result in Fig. 11(a), when copper is doped on g-C 3 N 4 (Cug-C 3 N 4 TiO 2 ), the yield of CH 3 OH is low for both visible and UV light, but when it is doped on TiO 2 (g-C 3 N 4 CuTiO 2 ) the yield of the products increase.It can be seen that doping Cu on TiO 2 could improve the efficiency and selectivity for CH 3 OH synthesis from CO 2 photoreduction 37 as similarly reported elsewhere 37.Another reason is that in the case of

result.query:
Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.
Please only select the generation from the provided possible choices.
Possible Choices:
Light_source: ['UV', 'Solar', 'UV-Vis', 'Monochromatic', 'Solar Simulator']
Lamp: ['Fluorescent', 'Mercury', 'Halogen', 'Mercury-Xenon', 'LED', 'Tungsten', 'Xenon', 'Tungsten-Halide', 'Solar Simulator']
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
Light_source: XXX
Lamp: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: inlet pipe at the top and gas products flowed out through an outlet pipe drawn into the reactor from the top.The light source radiated into the slurry photoreactor through a lamp compartment which extended into the reactor from the top.A 254 nm UV lamp (UVP 90-0004-01 3SC9 Pen-Ray Mercury gas Lamp) with an intensity of 5.4 mWcm 2 was used as the light source.The temperature of the reactor was maintained at 25 C by circulating cold water from a chiller.0.2 g of the as-prepared photocatalyst was dissolved in

Pyrex glass vessel having a hollow and two angled joints for cooling water inlet and outlet.A 500 W, 22 cm long arc Xe-lamp tube (PLS-LAX500ADJ, Perfect light Technology Co., Ltd.) was employed as the visible light source.The xenon lamp was placed inside the hollow of the cold trap for cooling the heat generated from the lamp and to filter infrared heat.0.1 g of the catalyst and 200 mL of 1.0 M NaOH solution was fed into the reactor.In order to purge the reactors and for saturation of CO 2 in the reaction

degassing at 250 C for 4 h and analyzed by the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method.The Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) diffuse reflection spectra of the samples were determined using a Shimadzu UV 3101PC UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer.The band gap energies of the photocatalysts were determined by using the Kubelka-Munk theory of reflectance and extrapolating from its plot.The charge recombination rate was measured using a Perkin Elmer LS 55 Luminescence Spectrophotometer.In order to determine the chemical

voltage of 200 kV. The photocatalytic reaction was conducted in two different setups; one for the UV-light photoreaction and the other for visible light reaction as depicted in Fig. 1.The UV light photoreaction process was carried out in a jacketed Pyrex glass slurry photoreactor with a total volume of 500 mL.Cooling water from a chiller was passed through the jacketed wall of the reactor to control the temperature.CO 2 is fed into the slurry photoreactor through a gas inlet pipe at the top and gas

of CO 2 in the reaction medium, pure CO 2 gas was injected into the solution in each set-up for 30 min at a flow rate of 20 mLmin with the UV or visible light switched off.The solution was then irradiated using the light source for each set-up and samples were withdrawn every 2 h interval using a syringe.The drawn samples were filtered using a 0.45 mm filter in order to remove particles of the catalyst. The products were analysed and measured using a Perkin Elmer GC Auto system XL Gas Chromatograph

photocatalyst was dissolved in 400 mL of 1 M NaOH inside the slurry type photoreactor using a magnetic stirrer.The gas inlet port is connected to the reactor while the gas outlet port comes from the reactor for gas samples to be collected.The compressed gas (CO 2 purity 99.99) was regulated using a mass flow controller. The visible light photoreaction consisted of a reactor made from Pyrex glass of total volume of 250 mL.The quartz cold trap (QW220, China) was a double-jacketed Pyrex glass vessel having a

voltage of 200 kV. order to determine the chemical composition of the catalyst a Shimadzu Axis Ultra DLD X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy was used.The photocatalyst was fixed to the sample holder using a carbon tape.The pass energy used for the survey spectra was 160 eV while that of the high resolution was 20 eV.The survey spectra were recorded in the range of 0-1200 eV.The structure of the samples were analyzed using transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL), operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV.
